On September 3, the Great Neck Public Schools was pleased to host Nassau County elected officials and law enforcement officials as they discussed county-wide school safety efforts ahead of the new school year. Nassau County Executive Laura Curran, Police Commissioner Patrick Ryder, and County Legislator Ellen Birnbaum held a press briefing outside Parkville School, where they were joined by GNPS Superintendent Dr. Teresa Prendergast, Security Director Richard Castro, and Parkville Principal Kathleen Murray.

Our partnerships with law enforcement are a vital component of our district’s safety and security plan. Officers from the Nassau County Police Department and local Village police departments are visible in our schools, work cooperatively with our staff and security personnel, participate in our safety drills, and provide training throughout the school year. We thank all our law enforcement for their support in maintaining a safe school community. #DiscoverGreatness

North High and South High graduates and their families celebrated commencement earlier this week with memorable drive-in movie experiences at the Town of North Hempstead Beach Park.

High school and district administrators welcomed families for the South High event on June 22, followed by the North High event on June 23. With social distancing measures and safety precautions in place, these events provided the senior classes an opportunity to come together as an audience to view the graduation movies from their vehicles.

The movies were also made available online for graduates who wished to watch from home. Graduation movies for our secondary schools will air on GNPS/TV at a later date.

Thank you to the Town of North Hempstead for offering this beautiful venue for these memorable commencement events. Congratulations to the Class of 2020! #GreatNeckStrong #DiscoverGreatness

JFK Morning Meetings continue to take place on Zoom, where students chat, share, and play games as they do in the classroom. Each week, this fifth-grade class continues with the daily JFK schedule, including Mindful Monday, Idiom of the Week, and a favorite, Kindness Wednesday.

South High Theatre Production students prepare a special performance for Lakeville third graders each spring. This year, the high school students created a virtual theatrical adventure that ties into an emotions unit that the younger students are currently engaged in through remote learning.

Theatre Production students were tasked with brainstorming and researching emotions that a third-grader may feel during this uncertain time, assigning roles for each emotion, and recording and editing their videos. The end product, "Quarantine Adventure: Choose Your Emotion," features eight short videos relating to how students may feel during this time: energetic, bored, thankful, sad, overwhelmed, silly, hopeful, or mixed emotions.

The videos were shared with Lakeville third-graders via YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL9XzVbNp0lxrSR2Lx8LY0WirVMz8JASsG

#GreatNeckStrong #DiscoverGreatness

South High School's awarding-winning robotics team, Rebel Robotics, celebrated their annual year-end reception via Zoom on June 3. More than 75 team members, parents, mentors, and supporters participated in the celebration, which included an overview of the robotics season and the team's accomplishments.

Awards were also given out to various students for safety, leadership, volunteerism and all-around team support. Dr. Gitz, principal of South High, was honored with the "Rebel With A Cause" award for his unwavering support of the robotics program.

Each of the seniors on the team were singled out for their dedication and spoke about the impact that Rebel Robotics had on them during high school.

Administrators Dr. Prendergast, Dr. Lando, Ms. Newman, Dr. Gitz, Dr. Applebaum, and Mr. Gimondo were on hand to offer congratulatory words, as were Board of Education Trustees Ms. Sassouni and Mr. Shi. Rebel Robotics is led by mentors Mr. Motchkavitz, Mr. Corrigan, Ms. Zinn and Mr. Passuello. #DiscoverGreatness #GreatNeckStrong

With the help of elementary school administrators, social workers, and classroom teachers, the district was able to identify families with students in PreK through grade 3 in need of a technology loan program during this school closure. Together with our Instructional Technology 1:1 iPad Initiative for grades 3-12, these efforts are providing more equitable access to remote learning and helping to close the digital divide in our community. #GreatNeckStrong #DiscoverGreatness

On February 8–9, seven robotics teams from GNPS competed at the regional FIRST LEGO League (FLL) robotics competition. Our FIRST LEGO League (FLL) robotics teams are gearing up for a regional tournament this weekend! GNPS will be represented by 7 teams, including 1 team from each middle school and 5 brand-new elementary teams.

This will be the first FLL competition for our new elementary robotics enrichment program, which features a total of 50 students from all four of our elementary schools. This program offers a rare educational opportunity for students from different schools to work together as teammates.

Financial support for this new elementary enrichment program has been provided through the Lewis E. Love Memorial Science Education Award, which was established by the North High School Class of 1963 to support science education in our district. The award was created in memory of Mr. Love, a beloved science teacher in Great Neck for more than 40 years, who inspired many students to pursue a career in science.

Good luck to all our students and mentors at the FLL competition this weekend! #DiscoverGreatness
